meanings.def: used before plural or uncountable nouns to mean ‘as many or as much as somebody needs or wants’
examples: Have you made enough copies?
Is there enough room for me?
I didn't have enough clothes to last a week.
Don't ask me to do it. I've got enough problems as it is.
(old-fashioned) There was food enough for all.

related: too many chiefs and not enough Indians
enough/something to be going on with
curiously, funnily, oddly, strangely, etc. enough
old enough to be somebody’s father/mother

meanings.def: as many or as much as somebody needs or wants
examples: Six bottles should be enough.
Have you had enough (= to eat)?
If enough of you are interested, we'll organize a trip to the theatre.
There was nowhere near enough for everybody.
We've nearly run out of paper. Do you think there's enough for today?

meanings.def: used to say that something is annoying or boring and that you want it to stop
used when you think that something should not continue any longer
used to say that you understand a situation and there is no need to say any more
examples: ‘He's a politician, remember.’ ‘Enough said.’

meanings.def: used when something/somebody is annoying you and you no longer want to do, have or see it or them
examples: I've had enough of driving the kids around.

idioms.def: used to say that something is annoying or boring and that you want it to stop
used when you think that something should not continue any longer
used to say that you understand a situation and there is no need to say any more
examples: ‘He's a politician, remember.’ ‘Enough said.’

idioms.def: used when something/somebody is annoying you and you no longer want to do, have or see it or them
examples: I've had enough of driving the kids around.
I hadn't trained enough for the game.
This house isn't big enough for us.
She's old enough to decide for herself.
We didn't leave early enough.
They've been in this business long enough to know what they're doing.
Tell them it's just not good enough.

meanings.def: to an acceptable degree, but not to a very great degree
examples: He seemed pleasant enough to me.

meanings.def: to a degree that you do not wish to get any greater
examples: I hope my job's safe. Life is hard enough as it is.
Things are bad enough without you having a meltdown.

meanings.def: to be strong or brave enough
examples: He was not man enough to face up to his responsibility.

meanings.def: used to show that something is surprising
examples: Funnily enough, I said the same thing myself only yesterday.

meanings.def: used to say that an idea or suggestion seems reasonable
examples: ‘We'll meet at 8.’ ‘Fair enough.’
If you don't want to come, fair enough, but let Bill know.

meanings.def: to achieve all that is wanted
examples: The new legislation is welcome but does not go far enough.
Do these measures go far enough?
(disapproving) Stop it now. The joke has gone far enough (= it has continued too long).
She would be in bed by now, like enough.

meanings.def: used to say that something is so nearly true that the difference does not matter
examples: We've been here twenty years, near enough.

meanings.def: certainly; in a way that cannot be denied
examples: You heard me right enough (= so don't pretend that you did not).

meanings.def: used to say that something happened as expected
examples: I said he'd forget, and sure enough he did.
‘Stop,’ she said, ‘I can hear something.’ Sure enough, in the distance we could hear the sound of a car approaching.

idioms.idiom: be man enough (to do something/for something)
idioms.def: to be strong or brave enough
examples: He was not man enough to face up to his responsibility.

idioms.idiom: curiously, funnily, oddly, strangely, etc. enough
idioms.def: used to show that something is surprising
examples: Funnily enough, I said the same thing myself only yesterday.

idioms.def: used to say that an idea or suggestion seems reasonable
examples: ‘We'll meet at 8.’ ‘Fair enough.’
If you don't want to come, fair enough, but let Bill know.

idioms.def: to achieve all that is wanted
examples: The new legislation is welcome but does not go far enough.
Do these measures go far enough?
(disapproving) Stop it now. The joke has gone far enough (= it has continued too long).
She would be in bed by now, like enough.

idioms.def: used to say that something is so nearly true that the difference does not matter
examples: We've been here twenty years, near enough.

idioms.def: certainly; in a way that cannot be denied
examples: You heard me right enough (= so don't pretend that you did not).

idioms.def: used to say that something happened as expected
examples: I said he'd forget, and sure enough he did.
‘Stop,’ she said, ‘I can hear something.’ Sure enough, in the distance we could hear the sound of a car approaching.
